section_title: Power by order to make provision reforming law which imposes burdens
Document to be laid before Parliament
Representations made in confidence or containing damaging information
Codes of practice relating to enforcement of regulatory requirements
Making of codes of practice by Ministers of the Crown
Making of codes of practice by National Assembly for Wales

section_text: 13 1 In section 6 of the 1994 Act (model provisions with respect to appeals), in subsection (7)— a . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . b for the definition of “interested person” there is substituted— “ interested person ” means— a the person against whom enforcement action may be or has been taken; b any other person who will or may be required to meet, or to make a significant contribution towards, the cost of observing the restriction or complying with the requirementor condition; or c where the enforcement action which may be or has been taken relates specifically to goods or services which are to be or have been supplied by a person other than the oneagainst whom enforcement action may be or has been taken, that person; . 2 This section does not extend to Scotland.
14 In this Act— “ the 1994 Act ” means the Deregulation and Contracting Out Act 1994 (c. 40); ... ... ... ...
15 1 This Act may be cited as the Regulatory Reform Act 2001. 2 This Act extends to Northern Ireland. 3 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
